There is something corrupt when professional creditors and financial advisers lend to countries, which they know cannot afford to repay them. Were they planning to purchase a country on disclosure? Make a profit out of some destitute people and take their livelihood away?

Michael the fact is that the Confederate flag belonged to a group of rebels who actually lost a war.  Whilst the Union Jack may or may not be seen as a the symbol you claim it to be, there is no doubt that the Confederate flag represented a self proclaimed country that waged war and lost.

The difference is Great Britain is a sovereign nation. Wales was conquered by the English nearly a thousands years ago, as was Ireland. Scotland merged with England because they shared a monarch. The Union Flag incorporates symbols of Ireland, Scotland and England; unfortunately not Wales which the English never saw as a sovereign nation. While a good part of Ireland gained full independence from Great Britain nearly seventy years ago. Northern Ireland is still part of Great Britain.

The Union flag represents just that; the political union of the four kingdoms - England, Ireland, Scotland & Wales. To be offended by that flag is to be offended by the idea of the Union. Scotland just held a referendum and voted to stay in the Union. Does you comparing the British Union flag to the confederate battle flag imply you advocate secession from the United States of America?

The same could be said of many national flags. How do Native Americans feel about the U.S. flag? How do the Chinese people feel about the Rising Sun of your adoptive country? The Confederate battle flag  is not a national flag. This is a time for rational, moderate thinking

The Union Jack is a symbol of oppression to Irish People and should be removed because it is deeply offensive and dredges up memories of the centuries of British Oppression, killing, starving and cruelty towards the Irish Nation.

The Welsh People find the Union Jack to be deeply offensive for similar reasons of British savagery towards the people of Wales.

The Scottish people find the Union Jack to be deeply offensive as well.

Just as the Confederate flag is offensive to black Americans--the Union Jack is a profoundly offensive and hateful symbol of oppression and it must be removed from our society immediately.
The confederate flag represents treason and racial hatred, what don't you see through those rose tinted glasses...

@Rollo, I think your argument better applies to Germany beating France in the QF, when, refereeing aside, the French were conspicuously profligate in front of net (Necib in the first minute and Thiney in the 118th most consequentially).
On the other hand, England forced three tremendous saves out of the Japanese keeper who had done nothing earlier inthe tournament to suggest she had those saves in her. In the second half, England not only got into the right positions, their shots were dangerous and on target, not right down the middle. They were effectively beaten by the Japanese keeper.

Well, I'd argue that my argument applies equally well to each.

Stats are trailing indicators trying to quantify and explain the
at times unexplainable. They are not predictors of what must happen or who deserves to win.

My argument is that the score is by far the best and most beautiful expression of who deserves to win.

Obviously, the Japanese keeper had the saves in her so when England watched the tape maybe they just tipped the ole cap.
Wow, where did that come from? Or maybe, they found some things they could have done differently whilst still tipping the cap.

The mystery to me is this vague and strange notion of fairness, as if doing the most things right, dominating play, entitles you to come out on top. It doesn't work in life, so why should it work in sports?

That great baseball writer Roger Angell had it, I think, when he said -- there are not just two teams -- there are two teams and then there is the game. The game is the wildcard -- sometimes you do everything right and it comes out wrong. That's the game.

Or as Branch Rickey had it, you can be good, or you can be lucky and if you have to pick one, pick lucky,

There is a place for metrics as an adjunct to a sport but this article strays into the land of metrics inflating itself to the level of pompous ass when it asserts that England “deserved to win”.
No it didn’t. It lost and it deserved to lose.
I would not argue if the argument is that England dominated play and while that is interesting, it is also so what? The world of sports has always been littered with teams that dominated play BUT -- failed to capitalize, failed to seal the deal, failed to WIN.
You know, missed the object of the exercise.
And I also think our friends the statisticians have overlooked another vital point.
So okay, sure – some shots are better than others, but some players are better than others. So if you assign a value to position on the pitch from which the shot is struck, should you not also assign a value to the talent of the player who struck it?
Or do we say that Messi is just another guy and the three he put in the back of the net were interesting, but all from bad angles --so sorry the other fellas win, because they had more attempts from better positions even though none went in?
Do we say the basketball team with the best shot selection deserved to win? The golfer with the shortest total length of putts deserved to win?
No, we say, as Mr. Hickman of the ’62 Mets said all too frequently that “we snatched defeat from the jaws of victory”.
Yes, statistics are for losers. So study the tape England -- and find some finishers.

My dad was a brave soul. He had a triple bypass at 83 and as a result of a botched recovery room routine got two bed sores on his heels. One turned gangrenous and he lost his leg. Above the knee. The bypass was a complete success however. He learned to to use a wheelchair and had good care and made a miraculous recovery. He had 5 more years before his body had just had enough and he made his wishes very clear. No heroic interventions, let nature take it's course, just keep him comfortable and let him talk to his 5 kids, my mom and his 6 grand kids. And he talked and talked. The time we had was precious. He was funny and reflective and  didn't dwell on his condition, because he knew what lay ahead. But he had 88 years of wisdom to impart and did not want any interruptions.  To me, he dictated a list of clients that owed him money. My job, he said,  was to collect it. I should be willing he advised to accept no less than 75 cents on the dollar.  He gave me special instructions on certain deadbeats and admonished me to not let them"off the hook".  My other siblings were each tasked with other projects. On November 15th 2010 my brother called me from the hospice and told me our dad had slipped away and he was gone. No suffering, no pain, just gone.

Kalief Browder served three years, two of them in solitary, for a crime he claimed someone else committed. More importantly, the writer implies, young Mr. Browder served this time while awaiting trial because he didn't have the $3,000 he needed to make bail.

He served some or all of his incarceration, then, without having been convicted, in harsh conditions, for the dubious 'crime' of being poor. Imagine the public outcry if, instead of needing $3,000 to be released on bail, judges determined eligibility for pre-trial release on the basis of who can dunk a basketball.

Would those who argue that setting bail at "$3,000" for every person accused of committing the same class of crime is "equal protection" also think it equal protection to ask the same set of detainees to dunk?

A majority of the population would be unable to qualify for release on the sheer bases of age, size, and ability -- attributes hardly more resistant to imminent modification than a 22-year-old's socioeconomic standing and personal wealth.

Under such conditions, holding people who aren't flight risks would constitute a mockery of equal protection.

I have not read one article since all this started in which the writer (if it is an economist) has believed that the Greek debt is payable.  The Greek national product is not high enough.  Now at the last minute  the IMF comes along and states that 50 billion dollars of that debt should be forgiven.  Others have said even more than that.  So, maybe I am too simple, but it looks like the solution is obvious.  In exchange for Greeks pushing up the retirement age, agreeing to establish a workable mechanism for collecting taxes, a huge amount of the Greek debt should be forgiven.  The alternatives are odious.  Continuing depression in Greece, civil disorder and chaos, wasting of two or three generations, and most fearfully for the defense of Europe could be an alliance of Greece with Putin's Russia and a weakening of the NATO defense system. I, for one, cannot believe this is happening after all the European continent has gone through during the past hundreds of years with continual battles between big states and various ethnic groups killing each other in little wars we never hear about.  Why are the Europeans letting this happen again in which states are pitted against each other.  It is a tremendously dangerous development in which the instigating factor might be this solvable problem of Greek indebtedness.
